questions.question: Which of the following combinations correctly describes the effect on Glomerular Filtration Rate (GFR) given the status of the afferent and efferent arterioles?

options.D: Efferent arteriole mild constriction - GFR increased

questions.explanation: Correct answer: D ) Efferent arteriole mild constriction - GFR increase Explanation: T he effect of efferent arteriolar constriction depends on the severity of the constriction; modest efferent constriction raises GFR, but severe efferent constriction (more than a threefold increase in resistance) tends to reduce GFR. Constriction of the efferent arterioles increases the resistance to outflow from the glomerular capillaries. This mechanism raises glomerular hydrostatic pressure and, as long as the increase in efferent resistance does not reduce renal blood flow too much, GFR increases slightly Arteriole Change Effect on Resistance Effect on Glomerular Hydrostatic Pressure Effect on GFR Afferent Arteriole Constriction Increases Decreases Decreases Afferent Arteriole Dilation Decreases Increases Increases Efferent Arteriole Constriction- Mild Increases Increases Slight increase Efferent Arteriole Constriction- Severe Increases Increases Initially increases GFR then ultimately decreases. Severe efferent arteriole constriction reduces renal blood flow and increases filtration fraction, concentrating plasma proteins in the glomerular capillaries and elevating glomerular colloid osmotic pressure. This counteracts the effect of increased hydrostatic pressure, ultimately reducing GFR Efferent Arteriole Dilation Decreases Decreases Decreases Reference: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 14th Edition, Page 333-335

questions.question: A physiologist is studying the effect of food additives on GFR in order to determine what additives should be avoided in individuals with CKD. Caffeine was found to affect urine output through an effect on GFR. What is the effect and the mechanism involved?

options.A: Increase urine output; afferent arteriole vasodilation
options.B: Increase urine output; efferent arteriole vasodilation
options.C: Increase urine output; afferent arteriole vasoconstriction
options.D: Decrease urine output; afferent arteriole vasodilation

questions.explanation: Correct answer: A) Increase urine output; afferent arteriole vasodilation Explanation: Caffeine's primary effect is to increase urine output via afferent arteriole vasodilation . Caffeine causes relaxation of the smooth muscle in the afferent arterioles This vasodilation increases blood flow into the glomeruli. The increase in blood flow raises the hydrostatic pressure within the glomeruli, leading to an increased GFR. A higher GFR means that more plasma is filtered into the renal tubules. With a higher GFR, more filtrate is produced, which ultimately results in an increase in urine volume. Increase urine output; efferent arteriole vasodilation (Option B) : This would decrease glomerular pressure and GFR, leading to lower urine output. Increase urine output; afferent arteriole vasoconstriction (Option C) : Vasoconstriction would reduce blood flow into the glomeruli, decreasing GFR and urine output. Decrease urine output; afferent arteriole vasodilation (Option D) : Afferent arteriole vasodilation increases GFR and urine output, not decreases it. Reference: Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, Page 679

questions.question: A 56-year-old man is admitted to the ED with an acute myocardial infarction. The man was transferred to the CCU and was placed on 24 h intake and output. A few days later his 24 hr urinary output was decreased. An increase in which of the following contributes to the reduced urine flow in a patient with congestive heart failure?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: D) Renal sympathetic nerve activity Explanation: In a patient with congestive heart failure, reduced urine flow is primarily due to an increase in renal sympathetic nerve activity. Renal Sympathetic Nerve Activity: Promotes a decrease in sodium and water excretion by: Decreasing glomerular filtration rate (GFR). Increasing renin secretion, leading to further fluid retention via the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system. Enhancing tubular sodium reabsorption. ANP (Atrial Natriuretic Peptide) (Option A) : Typically promotes diuresis and sodium excretion; its levels are often lower in heart failure due to decreased atrial stretch. Urodilatin (Option B) : A natriuretic peptide isolated from human urine, synthesized in kidney tubular cells. It is a 32-amino-acid peptide processed from the same precursor as ANP. Acts as a paracrine regulator of sodium and water homeostasis in the distal nephron. Increases sodium and water excretion by interacting with luminal receptors in the distal and connecting tubules, but its action may be blunted in heart failure. Renal Perfusion Pressure (Option C) : While decreased due to heart failure, this does not directly increase urine flow; it typically leads to retention. Reference: Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, Page 693,694

questions.question: Which of the following best describes what happens to the PAH excretion rate when the plasma concentration of PAH exceeds the transport maximum (Tm)? level. concentration beyond a level..

options.A: The excretion rate continues to increase linearly with increasing plasma concentration upto a certain
options.B: The excretion rate reaches a plateau and remains constant despite further increases in plasma
options.C: The excretion rate decreases with increasing plasma concentration.
options.D: The excretion rate first increases linearly, then decreases after reaching the transport maximum.

questions.explanation: increases in plasma concentration beyond a level.. Correct Answer: B) The excretion rate reaches a plateau and remains constant despite further increases in plasma concentration. Explanation: Transport Maximum - The highest rate at which a substance can be reabsorbed or secreted by the renal tubules of the kidneys. Significance: Diagnostic Tool: It aids in diagnosing conditions like diabetes mellitus (glycosuria) and renal tubular disorders. Homeostasis: Tm ensures efficient essential nutrients and electrolytes reabsorption, maintaining body homeostasis. Drug Excretion: It influences the excretion of drugs and toxins, impacting pharmacokinetics and dosing regimens. Pathophysiology: T m provides insights into kidney function and the pathophysiology of diseases affecting renal transport mechanisms. Clinical Monitoring: It assists in monitoring the progression and treatment of kidney diseases and other metabolic conditions. When the plasma concentration of PAH exceeds the transport maximum (T m ), the renal tubules are saturated and cannot secrete PAH any faster. As a result, the excretion rate reaches a plateau and does not increase further despite increasing plasma concentrations of PAH. PAH Plasma conc. Vs clearance rate The excretion rate does not continues to increase linearly with increasing plasma concentration as the transport mechanisms in the kidneys have a maximum capacity (Tm), beyond which they cannot increase the rate of PAH excretion, causing the rate to plateau. (Option A) The excretion rate should remain at the maximum capacity of the transport mechanisms (T m ) and not decrease. (Option C) While it correctly states that the excretion rate initially increases linearly, it inaccurately suggests that the rate decreases after reaching the transport maximum. The excretion rate plateaus and remains constant after reaching Tm, without decreasing. (Option D)

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a component of the juxtaglomerular (JG) apparatus?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Loop of Henle Explanation: Loop of Henle: A segment of the nephron in the kidney's medulla. It is involved in concentrating urine and reabsorbing water and solutes. However, it is not part of the juxtaglomerular apparatus. JuxtaGlomerular Apparatus(JG) : Crucial for regulating kidney function and blood pressure Significance: Renin Release: Juxtaglomerular cells secrete renin in response to low blood pressure, low sodium chloride concentration, or sympathetic nervous system stimulation. Renin-Angiotensin-Aldosterone System (RAAS): Renin initiates the RAAS, leading to the production of angiotensin II, which increases blood pressure by constricting blood vessels and stimulating aldosterone release to retain sodium and water. Blood Pressure Regulation: JGA plays a vital role in maintaining systemic blood pressure and fluid balance. Glomerular Filtration Rate (GFR) Regulation: Macula densa cells sense changes in sodium chloride and help adjust the GFR by influencing afferent arteriole constriction or dilation. Homeostasis: Essential for maintaining electrolyte balance, blood volume, and overall homeostasis. Consists of 3 components: Macula densa Juxtaglomerular cells/Granular cells Extraglomerular mesangial cells/Lacis cells Macula densa: A specialised group of epithelial cells located in the distal convoluted tubule adjacent to the glomerulus. They detect sodium concentration in the filtrate and help regulate blood pressure and filtration rate. Juxtaglomerular cells/Granular cells: Specialised smooth muscle cells in the walls of the afferent arterioles. They produce and secrete renin, crucial in regulating blood pressure and electrolyte balance. Extraglomerular mesangial cells/Lacis cells: It is located between the afferent and efferent arterioles and the distal convoluted tubule. They are thought to assist in signalling between the macula densa and juxtaglomerular cells.

questions.question: Which of the following best explains the relationship between creatinine clearance (CrCl) and glomerular filtration rate (GFR)?

options.A: Creatinine clearance is a direct measure of GFR.
options.B: Creatinine clearance is an indirect measure of GFR and typically overestimates GFR.
options.C: Creatinine clearance underestimates GFR because it accounts for tubular secretion of creatinine.

questions.explanation: GFR. Correct Answer: B) Creatinine clearance is an indirect measure of GFR and typically overestimates GFR. Explanation: Creatinine Clearance measures how effectively the kidneys filter creatinine from the blood. It estimates the glomerular filtration rate (GFR), reflecting overall kidney function. The measurement involves collecting urine over 24 hours and taking a blood sample to determine the creatinine concentration in both urine and blood. Normal creatinine clearance is 140 mL/min. Creatinine clearance is an indirect measure of GFR and typically overestimates GFR. (Option B) Creatinine clearance is often used to estimate GFR. However, it tends to overestimate GFR because creatinine is filtered by the glomeruli and secreted in small amounts by the renal tubules. Creatinine clearance is not a direct measure of GFR. (Option A) It is the amount of blood filtered by the glomeruli per minute, and creatinine clearance approximates this value by measuring the clearance of creatinine, a waste product, from the blood. Creatinine clearance does not underestimate GFR. (Option C) Tubular secretion of creatinine would cause creatinine clearance to be overestimated, not underestimated, in the GFR. The additional creatinine secreted by the tubules leads to a higher clearance rate than the actual filtration rate. Reference: Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, Page 667

questions.question: Which of the following statements about "free water clearance" (C H2O ) is correct? Free water clearance = C H2O Urine osmolality = U osm Plasma osmolality = P osm Urine flow rate = V I hypertonic. I ). I )/ P osm. hypotonic.

options.A: Free water clearance is positive when the urine is hypotonic and negative when the urine is
options.B: Free water clearance is the same as urine flow rate (V
options.C: Free water clearance is calculated using C H2O = U osm (V
options.D: Free water clearance is positive when the urine is hypertonic and negative when the urine is

questions.explanation: the urine is hypertonic. Correct Answer: A) Free water clearance is positive when the urine is hypotonic and negative when the urine is hypertonic. Explanation: Free Water Clearance: Measure of the kidney's ability to excrete or conserve free water, independent of solute excretion. Free water clearance is positive when the urine is hypotonic and negative when the urine is hypertonic. Free water clearance reflects the ability of the kidneys to excrete or conserve water. When urine is hypotonic (less concentrated than plasma), the kidneys excrete more free water, making C H2O positive. When urine is hypertonic (more concentrated than plasma), the kidneys conserve water, making C H2O negative. Free water clearance is not the same as urine flow rate. (Option B) It is derived from the difference between the urine flow rate and the osmolar clearance , i ndicating that it adjusts the urine flow rate by the osmotic concentration of the urine compared to plasma. Free water clearance is calculated using the formula: (Option C) Reference: Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, Page 677

questions.question: A patient's hematocrit (the fraction of blood volume occupied by red blood cells) is 40%. The patient's renal plasma flow (RPF) is measured to be 600 mL/min. What is this patient's renal blood flow (RBF)?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) 1000 mL/min Explanation: Renal Blood Flow (RBF): The volume of blood delivered to the kidneys per unit of time. Typically, RBF is about 1.0 to 1.2 liters per minute in a healthy adult, accounting for approximately 20-25% of the cardiac output. Renal Plasma Flow (RPF): Volume of plasma (the liquid part of blood without cells) that passes through the kidneys per unit of time. It reflects the effective blood flow that is available for filtration in the kidneys. RPF is usually about 55-60% of the total renal blood flow. Renal blood flow (RBF) can be calculated using the formula: RBF = RPF/1- Hematocrit Given: Renal Plasma Flow (RPF) = 600 mL/min Hematocrit = 0.40 RBF = 600/1-0.40 = 600/0.60 = 1000 mL/min. Reference: Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, Page 664,665

questions.question: Why is inulin clearance the gold standard for measuring glomerular filtration rate (GFR)? GFR.

options.A: Inulin is readily available and naturally produced in the body
options.B: Inulin is freely filtered and neither reabsorbed nor secreted, providing an accurate measurement of
options.C: Inulin has a high plasma concentration that enhances measurement accuracy
options.D: Inulin is rapidly metabolised by the kidneys, making it easier to measure

questions.explanation: accurate measurement of GFR. Correct answer: B) Inulin is freely filtered and neither reabsorbed nor secreted, providing an accurate measurement of GFR. Explanation Inulin clearance is a method for estimating glomerular filtration rate (GFR), a key indicator of kidney function. This method utilises inulin, a plant-derived polysaccharide, due to its unique properties: Freely Filtered: Inulin, similar to water, passes through the glomerular capillaries without restriction. Not Reabsorbed or Secreted: Inulin remains unchanged in the tubules, neither reabsorbed into the bloodstream nor secreted into the tubules. This ensures that the excretion rate of inulin accurately reflects the filtration rate by the glomeruli. To measure inulin clearance: Administer inulin intravenously (as it is not produced naturally in the body). Measure Plasma Inulin Concentration (Ps) : Reflects the amount of inulin in the blood. Measure Urine Inulin Concentration (Us) : Indicates the amount of inulin in the urine. Determine Urine Flow Rate (V) : Measures urine volume over time. Clearance Formula : ( Cs) = (Us x V) / Ps Us : Urine concentration of the substance V : Urine flow rate Ps : Plasma concentration of the substance Despite its accuracy, inulin clearance is less practical for routine use due to the need for intravenous administration. Therefore, other methods like creatinine clearance are more commonly used for estimating GFR in clinical settings. Reference: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 14th Edition, Page 360-364

questions.question: A patient has a urine concentration of a substance of 10 mg/mL, a urine flow rate of 2 mL/min, and a plasma concentration of that substance of 5 mg/mL. What is the clearance rate of this substance?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: A) 4 mL/min Explanation: Clearance measures the volume of plasma completely cleared of a substance by the kidneys per minute (mL/min), reflecting renal excretory efficiency. It is essential for evaluating kidney function, including filtration, reabsorption, and secretion processes. To calculate the clearance rate (Cs) of the substance, use the formula: Clearance Formula : ( Cs) = (Us x V) / Ps Us : Urine concentration of the substance V : Urine flow rate Ps : Plasma concentration of the substance Plugging in the values: Cs = (10 ×2)/5 = 4 ml /min So, the clearance rate of the substance is 4 mL/min . Types of Clearance Measurements: Inulin Clearance Used to measure Glomerular Filtration Rate (GFR) as it is freely filtered but not reabsorbed or secreted. Not ideal for routine use due to intravenous administration. Creatinine Clearance Estimates GFR using creatinine, which is primarily filtered by the glomeruli. Slightly inaccurate due to tubular secretion, but practical for clinical settings. PAH Clearance Estimates Renal Plasma Flow (RPF). PAH is cleared through both glomerular filtration and tubular secretion. Correction for PAH extraction ratio improves accuracy. Reference: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 14th Edition, Page 360-364

questions.question: A 65-year-old patient with severe renal artery stenosis is admitted for hypertension management. The physician decides to prescribe a medication to control the blood pressure but must avoid drugs that could adversely affect kidney function due to the existing renal impairment. Which drug is contraindicated in this patient due to the risk of worsening renal function?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor Explanation Renal artery stenosis reduces blood flow to the affected kidney, decreasing renal perfusion pressure. This decrease is perceived as threatening blood pressure homeostasis, triggering a cascade of events within the renin-angiotensin system. Increased angiotensin II levels help maintain GFR by constricting the efferent arteriole, preserving glomerular pressure despite reduced renal blood flow. ACE Inhibitors block the conversion of Angiotensin I to Angiotensin II, disrupting the compensatory mechanism and potentially causing a significant drop in GFR. ACE inhibitors can lead to acute renal failure in renal artery stenosis by reducing protective efferent arteriole constriction and worsening GFR. Beta-blockers (Option A) reduce blood pressure by decreasing heart rate and cardiac output. They do not directly affect renal perfusion or glomerular filtration rate. Calcium channel blockers (Option C) reduce blood pressure by relaxing blood vessels, including the arterioles. They do not significantly impair renal perfusion and are generally safe in patients with renal artery stenosis. Diuretics (Option D) help reduce blood pressure by increasing urine production and reducing fluid volume. While they must be used cautiously to avoid dehydration, they do not directly impair renal perfusion or GFR like ACE inhibitors. Reference: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 14th Edition, Page 338,340

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT an effect of angiotensin II?

options.A: Constriction of efferent arterioles in the kidneys
options.B: Decreased sodium reabsorption in the renal tubules
options.C: Stimulation of aldosterone release from the adrenal cortex

questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) Decreased sodium reabsorption in the renal tubules Explanation: Effects of Angiotensin II: 1 Renal Tubular Reabsorption Directly increases sodium reabsorption in proximal tubules, loops of Henle, distal tubules, and collecting tubules. (Option B) 2 Vasoconstriction Angiotensin II constricts arterioles, especially efferent arterioles in the kidneys, increasing glomerular pressure and maintaining GFR even at low blood pressure. (Option A) 3 Aldosterone Secretion Stimulates adrenal cortex to release aldosterone, enhancing sodium and water retention in the kidneys. (Option C) 4 Baroreflex Sensitivity Reduces baroreflex sensitivity in the brain, boosting its effects on blood pressure. 5 Thirst and Hormone Secretion Increases thirst, stimulates vasopressin (ADH) release for water reabsorption, and triggers ACTH secretion. (Option D) 6 Mesangial Cells Causes contraction of mesangial cells, potentially reducing GFR by decreasing filtration surface area 7 System Interactions Effects are influenced by sodium intake, blood volume, and other hormones. Active during low sodium or volume depletion to maintain GFR and fluid balance. Reference: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 14th Edition, Page 335,338,358,359 Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, Page 667, 690-692

questions.question: All of the following increase GFR except:
questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) Sympathetic Nerves Explanation: Mediator Effect on GFR Additional Notes Prostaglandins (PGE2, PGI2) (Option D) Increase Cause vasodilation; especially important in counteracting vasoconstriction from sympathetic nerves or angiotensin II Bradykinin (Option A) Increase Functions similarly to prostaglandins by causing vasodilation Nitric Oxide (Option B) Increases Important for maintaining normal renal excretion of sodium and water; decreased production linked to hypertension Angiotensin II Biphasic effect on GFR Constricts efferent arterioles, increasing glomerular pressure; severe constriction decreases GFR I Sympathetic Nerves (Option C) Decrease Cause vasoconstriction, especially under stress or volume depletion Norepinephrine, Epinephrine, Endothelin Decreases Vasoconstriction Reference: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 14th Edition, Page 333-342

questions.question: Which of the following statements about nephrons is correct? Total renal blood flow rate is 1000 to 1260 ml/minute Tubular reabsorption is the first step in urine production Chronic kidney disease occurs when there is a 75% reduction in the original number of nephrons. The cortical region of the kidney is most vulnerable to ischemia. Nephrons can regenerate after age 40. Maintains Acid-Base balance by secreting hydrogen ions and reabsorbing bicarbonate.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Statements 1, 3, and 6 . Explanation: Nephrons Structural and functional units of the kidney Number per Kidney 0.8 to 1.2 million (average of 1 million) Length 4.5 to 6.5 cm (average of 5 cm) Renal Blood Flow Total Blood Flow Rate: 1000 to 1260 ml/minute (20 to 25% of cardiac output) Blood Flow Distribution: Cortex: 90%, Medulla: 10% Vulnerability to Ischemia: The Medulla is prone to ischemia; the Corticomedullary junction is more vulnerable Plasma Flow Rate: 625 to 700 ml/minute through both kidneys combined Nephron Function Glomerular Filtration: First step in urine formation; filters water, ions, and small molecules from blood into Bowman's capsule Tubular Reabsorption: Process where the nephron removes water and solutes from the filtrate and returns them to the blood Tubular Secretion: Transfer of materials from blood into the tubular fluid Excretion: Final elimination of urine from the body Additional Functions Regulation of Blood Pressure: By controlling blood volume through reabsorption and secretion mechanisms Acid-Base Balance: By secreting hydrogen ions and reabsorbing bicarbonate Electrolyte Balance: By reabsorbing and secreting electrolytes such as sodium, potassium, calcium, and magnesium Erythropoietin Production: A hormone that stimulates red blood cell production in the bone marrow, especially in response to low oxygen levels in the blood Age-Specific Dynamics of Nephron Nephrons cannot regenerate. Nephron count decreases by 10% every 10 year after age 40. By age 80, about 40% of nephrons remain functional. Chronic kidney disease occurs when there is a 70 to 75% reduction in the original number of nephrons. Reference: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 14th Edition, Page 323,324. Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology, 26th edition, Page 661-667.

questions.question: Which of the following mechanisms is responsible for Myogenic Autoregulation of renal blood flow?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Calcium influx Explanation: Myogenic Autoregulation: It maintains relatively constant renal blood flow and GFR and may protect the kidney from hypertension-induced injury. Increased arterial pressure Increased stretch on renal blood vessels(particularly small arterioles) Increased calcium ion movement from the extracellular fluid into the cells Vascular smooth muscle contraction Prevents excessive vessel stretch and raises vascular resistance Reference: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 14th Edition, Page 341

questions.question: Calculate Renal Plasma Flow (RPF) if the GFR is 125 ml/min and the Filtration Fraction (FF) is 0.2.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) 625 Explanation: Filtration fraction is the fraction of renal plasma flow that is filtered. Filtration fraction = GFR/Renal Plasma Flow 0.2 = 125/Renal Plasma Flow Renal Plasma Flow = 125/0.2=625 Reference: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 14th Edition, Page 331

questions.question: Calculate the Net Filtration Pressure from the values given below: Glomerular Hydrostatic Pressure = 60 mmHg Bowman’s Capsule Pressure = 18 mmHg Glomerular Colloid Osmotic Pressure = 32 mmHg
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) 10 mmHg Explanation: Net filtration pressure = Glomerular hydrostatic pressure - Bowman’s capsule pressure - Glomerular colloid osmotic pressure = 60 - 18 - 32 =10. Forces Favoring Filtration: Glomerular Hydrostatic Pressure: 60 mm Hg Promotes filtration by pushing fluid out of the glomerular capillaries into Bowman's capsule. Forces Opposing Filtration: Bowman's Capsule Hydrostatic Pressure: 18 mm Hg Opposes filtration by pushing fluid back into the glomerular capillaries. 2. Glomerular Capillary Colloid Osmotic Pressure: 32 mm Hg The presence of plasma proteins prevents filtration by attracting water back into the glomerular capillaries. Net Filtration Pressure: Forces favouring filtration-Forces opposing filtration = 60 mm Hg - (18 mm Hg + 32 mm Hg) = 10 mm Hg Thus, healthy humans have a net filtration pressure of approximately 10 mm Hg. Reference: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology,14th Edition, Page 333

questions.question: If the molecular radius of a substance is 3.0 nm, it is known as:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Selectively permeable substance Explanation: The permeability of substances at the molecular filtration barrier is affected by their molecular diameter. Substances with 1.8-4.2 nm molecular radius are selectively permeable; their charges decide their permeability across the glomerular filtration barrier(order of permeability: positively charged substances > neutral substances > negatively charged substances). Type of substance Molecular radius Explanation Examples Freely filtrable <1.8 nm Easily pass through the barrier Sodium Potassium Water Urea Creatinine Inulin PAH Bicarbonate Selectively permeable 1.8-4.2 nm The charge on them determines filtration Albumin Haemoglobin Myoglobin Bence Jones proteins Impermeable >4.2 nm It cannot be filtered Reference: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 14th Edition, Page 332

questions.question: Which of the following diseases can be caused by the defects in proteins of the slit diaphragm?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) All of the above Explanation: The foot processes of podocytes form the 3rd and innermost layer of the glomerular filtration barrier The gaps between these foot processes are called slit pores or filtration slits A porous filtration slit diaphragm bridges the filtration slits Proteins in the slit diaphragm and diseases caused by the mutations of the genes coding for it: Protein Disease Nephrin Congenital Nephrotic Syndrome of Finnish type Podocin Steroid-Resistant Nephrotic Syndrome I -Actinin Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis Reference: G.K Pal Comprehensive Textbook of Medical Physiology, 1st Edition, Page 665 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK572058/ https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4377750/ https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5888331/

questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding the Glomerular Basement Membrane (GBM) is true?

options.A: It is not a part of the glomerular filtration barrier
options.D: Charges of substances do not affect their permeability through GBM

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Excludes substances larger than 8 nm Explanation: The Glomerular Basement Membrane is the layer of the glomerular filtration barrier. Layers of glomerular filtration barrier: Capillary endothelium Glomerular Basement Membrane (GBM) Foot processes of podocytes Glomerular Basement Membrane: Aspect Description Structure A specialized membrane forming a sheath shared by neighboring capillaries Contents Fine fibrils in a gel-like matrix The matrix contains type 4 collagen, laminin, fibronectin, and other negatively charged proteins Permeability Permits free passage of neutral substances up to 4 nm in diameter Excludes substances larger than 8 nm Molecular Charge Influence Charge on molecules affects their passage into Bowman's capsule. Reference: 1. G.K Pal Comprehensive Textbook of Medical Physiology, 1st Edition, Page 665 2. Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, Page 661 3. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3334451/

questions.question: Which of the following is the primary site of action of acetazolamide in the nephron?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Proximal convoluted tubule Explanation: Acetazolamide primarily acts on the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT) of the nephron. It works by inhibiting carbonic anhydrase, specifically types II and IV. Carbonic anhydrase plays a crucial role in the reabsorption of bicarbonate (HCO II ) in this segment. By inhibiting this enzyme, acetazolamide reduces the reabsorption of bicarbonate, leading to increased bicarbonate excretion and diuresis. The Loop of Henle (Option B) is primarily affected by loop diuretics, such as furosemide, which inhibit the Na-K-2Cl symporter in the thick ascending limb. The distal convoluted tubule (Option C) is the site of action for thiazide diuretics, which inhibit the Na-Cl symporter. Potassium-sparing diuretics, such as spironolactone and amiloride, act on the collecting duct. Acetazolamide does not have its primary action in the collecting duct. (Option D) Reference: Goodman and Gilman's The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th Edition, Page 562,563

questions.question: Which of the following characteristics correctly differentiates the Proximal Convoluted Tubule (PCT) from the Collecting Duct (CT)?

options.A: Paracellular transport present in CT and not in PCT
options.B: Brush border of epithelium present in PCT, not in CT
options.C: Tight junctions are tight in PCT and leaky in CT
options.D: Carbonic anhydrase type 4 absent in PCT, but present in CT

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Brush border of epithelium present in PCT, not in CT Explanation: Feature Proximal Convoluted Tubule (PCT) Collecting Duct (CT) Epithelium Type Simple cuboidal with brush border Simple cuboidal to columnar without brush border Brush Border Present Absent Microvilli Dense microvilli (forming brush border) Absent microvilli Paracellular Transport Significant due to leaky tight junctions Minimal due to tight tight junctions Tight Junctions Leaky Tight Carbonic Anhydrase Type 4 Present in microvilli Generally absent Mitochondrial Density High Lower than PCT Transport Mechanisms Active and passive Primarily passive Reabsorption of Glucose Almost complete Minimal Reference: G.K Pal, Comprehensive Textbook of Medical Physiology, 1st Edition, Page 661

questions.question: A 58-year-old patient with chronic renal failure presents with symptoms of fatigue, fluid retention, and low serum potassium levels. On examination, the patient shows signs of hypertension and oedema. Which of the following types of cells being defective in the renal tubules is responsible for the following condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Principal Cells Explanation Principal cells Sodium reabsorption and potassium secretion by the principal cells depend on the activity of a Na+-K+ ATPase pump in each cell’s basolateral membrane This pump maintains a low sodium concentration inside the cell and, therefore, favors sodium diffusion into the cell through special cheannels . The principal cells are the primary sites of action of the potassium-sparing diuretics , including spironolactone, eplerenone, amiloride, and triamterene. Cell Type Functions Characteristics Principal Cells (Option A) Sodium reabsorption Potassium secretion Water reabsorption Responsive to aldosterone ADH receptors Columnar epithelium Alpha Intercalated Cells (Option B) Secrete H I ions Reabsorb bicarbonate Apical H I -ATPases Cuboidal epithelium Beta Intercalated Cells (Option C) Secrete bicarbonate Reabsorb H I ions Apical bicarbonate transporters Cuboidal epithelium Juxtaglomerular Cells (Option D): They are located in the juxtaglomerular apparatus and are responsible for the secretion of renin, which plays a role in the regulation of blood pressure and the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system. They are not directly involved in sodium reabsorption, potassium secretion, or water reabsorption. Reference: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 14th Edition, Page 352,353.

questions.question: Which part of the proximal tubule is the most vulnerable and prone to ischemia?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) S3 Explanation: The proximal tubule is divided into three segments: S1, S2, and S3. Among these, S3 is the most vulnerable to ischemia. This increased susceptibility is due to the following reasons: High Metabolic Activity: S3 has the highest metabolic rate and density of mitochondria, making it more dependent on oxygen. Proximity to Renal Medulla: Located closer to the renal medulla, which has lower oxygen levels. Fewer Collateral Blood Vessels: S3 has less collateral circulation, reducing its ability to compensate for decreased blood flow. S1 S2 S3 Location Proximal to the glomerulus. Between S1 and S3. Near the loop of Henle. Function Reabsorption of nutrients, ions, and water. Reabsorption of water, ions, and bicarbonate. Reabsorption of sodium, bicarbonate, and nutrients. Features High brush border density. A brush border is present but less extensive than S1. High mitochondrial density. Risk of ischaemia Least prone Intermediate Most prone Reference: www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4967168/

questions.question: Match each component of the countercurrent system with its respective function: Components Functions 1. Ascending Limb of Loop of Henle a. Blood loses water and gains solutes as it passes through the hyperosmotic medullary interstitium. 2. Descending Limb of Loop of Henle b. Blood gains water and loses solutes as it passes through the less concentrated interstitium. 3. Ascending Vasa Recta c. Actively transports sodium and chloride into the interstitium, diluting the filtrate. 4. Descending Vasa Recta d. Permeable to water; water is reabsorbed into the interstitium, concentrating the filtrate.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) 1-c, 2-d, 3-b, 4-a Explanation: The countercurrent system is essential for maintaining the body's fluid and electrolyte balance, particularly through urine concentration. This system involves two main components in the kidneys: Countercurrent multiplier system in the loop of henle. Countercurrent exchanger system in the vasa recta. Countercurrent Multiplier System Countercurrent Exchanger System Location: Loop of Henle Location: Vasa Recta Function: Creates an osmotic gradient in the renal medulla to concentrate urine Function: Maintains the osmotic gradient established by the countercurrent multiplier system and supplies nutrients to the medulla Descending Limb: Permeable to water; water is reabsorbed into the interstitium, concentrating the filtrate Descending Vasa Recta: Blood loses water, and gains solute as it descends through the hyperosmotic medullary interstitium Ascending Limb: Impermeable to water; actively transports sodium and chloride out into the interstitium, diluting the filtrate Ascending Vasa Recta: Blood gains water and loses solutes as it ascends through the less concentrated interstitium. Mechanism: Countercurrent flow between descending and ascending limbs multiplies the osmotic gradient, enabling the concentration of urine Mechanism: Countercurrent exchange of water and solutes between blood in the vasa recta and the surrounding interstitium preserves the osmotic gradient

questions.question: Which of the following statements correctly differentiates between cortical and juxtamedullary nephrons? the renal medulla.

options.A: Cortical nephrons have longer loops of Henle.
options.B: Juxtamedullary nephrons constitute approximately 85% in the kidney.
options.C: Cortical nephrons usually have a higher filtration rate.
options.D: Juxtamedullary nephrons are located primarily in the renal cortex, whereas cortical nephrons are in

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Cortical nephrons usually have a higher filtration rate. Explanation: Cortical nephrons and Juxtamedullary nephrons: Feature Cortical Nephrons Juxtamedullary Nephrons Location Renal cortex. Near the boundary between the renal cortex and medulla. Percentage of Total Nephrons Approximately 85% Approximately 15% Loop of Henle Short and extends only into the outer medulla. Long and extends deep into the inner medulla. Vasa Recta Short and less extensive. Long vasa recta, which follows the loop of Henle into the medulla. Glomerular Capsule Has a larger surface area relative to the length of the loop of Henle. Smaller surface area relative to the length of the loop of Henle. Filtration Rate High Lower filtration rate but more specialised in concentration. Presence of Macula Densa Typically not present. These nephrons are closely associated with the juxtaglomerular apparatus. Function Primarily involved in regulating blood composition and volume through reabsorption and secretion. Concentration of urine due to the longer loops and extensive vasa recta Contributing to the medullary osmotic gradient. Reference: G.K Pal, Comprehensive Textbook of Medical Physiology, 1st edition, Page 663.
